H0.text: Speed is what can be learned about a wave by finding the product of the wavelength and frequency.

H1.text: Decibels are what we learn about a wave when we find the product of its wavelength and frequency.

H2.text: Volume is what can be learned about a wave by finding the product of its wavelength and frequency.

H3.text: Type is what we can learn about a wave by finding the product of the wavelength and frequency.

A4.text: Wave speed is a wave property, which may refer to absolute value of phase velocity, group velocity, signal velocity, or front velocity.

A5.text: Phase velocity, the velocity at which a wave phase propagates at a certain frequency.

A6.text: Signal velocity, or information velocity, is the velocity at which a wave carries information.

A7.text: Pulse wave velocity, the velocity at which a pulse travels through a medium, usually applied to arteries as a measure of arterial stiffness

A8.text: Group velocity, the propagation velocity for the envelope of wave groups and often of wave energy, different from the phase velocity for dispersive waves

A9.text: Front velocity, the velocity at which the first rise of a pulse above zero moves forward

A10.text: The speed of sound is proportional to the square root of the absolute temperature, giving an increase of about 0.6 m/s per degree Celsius.

A11.text: In solids, the speed of transverse (or shear) waves depends on the shear deformation under shear stress (called the shear modulus), and the density of the medium.

A12.text: Speed of sound: Temperature Matters, Not Air Pressure

A13.text: The value of c can then be found by using the relation c = λf.

A14.text: Another reason for the speed of light to vary with its frequency would be the failure of special relativity to apply to arbitrarily small scales, as predicted by some proposed theories of quantum gravity.

A15.text: The wavelength λ of a sinusoidal waveform traveling at constant speed v is given by λ = v/f.
